External Resource Links.Resource Title: Jim Crow and Plessy v. Ferguson

events.Text: Supreme Court validates separate-but-equal principle in _Plessy v. Ferguson_
events.Headline: Plessy v. Ferguson validates "separate but equal"
events.Name: 1896: Plessy v. Ferguson validates "separate but equal"

events.Text: A race riot organized by the white supremacist Redshirts in Wilmington, NC which led to the massacre of an estimated 14-60 blacks, the burning of the black newspaper "The Daily Record," the banishment of the legitimately elected biracial Fusion Party government, and the implementation of Jim Crow in North Carolina.
events.Headline: The Wilmington Race Riot implements Jim Crow in North Carolina
events.Name: 1898: The Wilmington Race Riot implements Jim Crow in North Carolina

External Resource Links.Resource Title: Niagara Movement - Cornerstone of the Modern Civil Rights Movement

events.Text: Niagara Movement, forerunner of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People (NAACP), formed for school integration, voting rights, and assisting black political candidates
events.Name: 1905: Niagara Movement, forerunner of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People (NAACP), formed for school integration, voting rights, and assisting black political candidates

events.Text: Greensburg, Indiana, race riot in reaction to black migration north.
events.Name: 1906: Greensburg, Indiana, race riot in reaction to black migration north.

events.Text: National Association for the Advancement of Colored People formed.
events.Name: 1909: National Association for the Advancement of Colored People formed.

events.Text: Movie _Birth of a Nation_ released; though a smash hit, its blatant racism provokes opposition from the newly formed NAACP and other black organizations.  This romanticization of the Ku Klux Klan led to its revival at Stone Mountain, GA.
events.Name: 1915: Movie Birth of a Nation released; though a smash hit, its blatant racism provokes opposition from the newly formed NAACP and other black organizations.  This romanticization of the Ku Klux Klan led to its revival at Stone Mountain, GA.

events.Text: On May 31 and June 1, 1921, in Tulsa Oklahoma, mobs of white residents, many deputized and armed by city officials, attacked black residents and businesses in the Greenwood District. It was at that time the wealthiest black community in the US and was known as "Black Wall Street."
events.Headline: Tulsa Race Massacre
events.Name: 1921: On May 31 and June 1, 1921, in Tulsa Oklahoma, mobs of white residents, many deputized and armed by city officials, attacked black residents and businesses in the Greenwood District. It was at that time the wealthiest black community in the US and was known as "Black Wall Street."

events.Text: The Durham County Confederate Soldiers Monument is dedicated.  Funded by taxes and organized by United Confederate Veterans and United Daughters of the Confederacy, the monument was erected in front of the County Courthouse.  The monument remained in that location until it was torn down in August 2017.
events.Name: 1924: The Durham County Confederate Soldiers Monument is dedicated.  Funded by taxes and organized by United Confederate Veterans and United Daughters of the Confederacy, the monument was erected in front of the County Courthouse.  The monument remained in that location until it was torn down in August 2017.

Images.caption: Louis Austin, Editor of The Carolina Times.
Images.alt_text: Louis Austin, seated behind a desk, reads an issue of the Carolina Times.
Images.attribution: Photographer: Unknown
Images.citation: Durham Historic Photographic Archive (NCC.0055), North Carolina Collection, Durham County Library, NC

events.Text: Louis Austin buys _Standard Advertiser_ newspaper, changes name to _Carolina Times._ With the motto "The Truth Unbridled," Austin used the _Carolina Times_ to re-energize black activism in Durham.
events.Name: 1927: Louis Austin buys Standard Advertiser newspaper, changes name to Carolina Times. With the motto "The Truth Unbridled," Austin used the Carolina Times to re-energize black activism in Durham.

events.Text: Thomas Hocutt, with the support of the NAACP, challenges white-only admissions at the University of North Carolina pharmacy school.  Because James Shepard would not release Hocutt's transcripts, the case was dismissed for lack of standing.  However, it served as a test case to challenging the "separate but equal" doctrine in education and laid the groundwork for _Brown v. Board of Education_.
events.Name: 1933: Thomas Hocutt, with the support of the NAACP, challenges white-only admissions at the University of North Carolina pharmacy school.  Because James Shepard would not release Hocutt's transcripts, the case was dismissed for lack of standing.  However, it served as a test case to challenging the "separate but equal" doctrine in education and laid the groundwork for Brown v. Board of Education.

External Resource Links.Resource Title: Durham Committee on the Affairs of Black People

events.Text: Durham Committee on Negro Affairs formed, beginning modern efforts for civil rights in Durham.  In its early years, the Committee focused on registering voters, running black candidates for local office for the first time in 1938, and getting blacks elected and appointed into positions typically reserved for whites.
events.Name: 1935: Durham Committee on Negro Affairs formed, beginning modern efforts for civil rights in Durham.  In its early years, the Committee focused on registering voters, running black candidates for local office for the first time in 1938, and getting blacks elected and appointed into positions typically reserved for whites.

events.Text: 68% of eligible black voters are registered in Durham County.
events.Name: 1939: 68% of eligible black voters are registered in Durham County.

External Resource Links.Resource Title: Southern Conference on Race Relations, Durham, N.C., October 20, 1942

events.Text: Black intellectuals meeting at North Carolina College draft Durham Manifesto for civil rights, leading to formation of Southern Regional Council in 1943.
events.Name: 1942: Black intellectuals meeting at North Carolina College draft Durham Manifesto for civil rights, leading to formation of Southern Regional Council in 1943.

events.Text: Congress of Racial Equality (CORE) founded.
events.Name: 1942: Congress of Racial Equality (CORE) founded.

events.Text: Confrontation between black GI stationed at Camp Butner and white ABC officer over liquor rations leads to race riot in the African-American neighborhood of Hayti.  A police officer and a white bus driver were injured.
events.Name: 1943: Confrontation between black GI stationed at Camp Butner and white ABC officer over liquor rations leads to race riot in the African-American neighborhood of Hayti.  A police officer and a white bus driver were injured.

External Resource Links.Resource Title: Miss Lyons Draws $5.00 Fine for Being Attacked

events.Text: Doris Lyons, 16, fined five dollars for refusing bus driver's order to "get in the back."  The arresting officer was absolved of the charge of assault and battery by the white judge proceeding over the case.
events.Name: 1943: Doris Lyons, 16, fined five dollars for refusing bus driver's order to "get in the back."  The arresting officer was absolved of the charge of assault and battery by the white judge proceeding over the case.

External Resource Links.Resource Title: JIM CROW LOSES; The Secret Game
A Courageous Act, Ahead of its Time

events.Text: A secret game of basketball is played between the Men's basketball team at the North Carolina College for Negroes (now North Carolina Central University) and the Duke University Medical School basketball team.  It was the first mixed-race sporting event in the modern South.  Due to the illegal nature of the game, the game was played on a Sunday morning when most of Durham, including the police would be in church and the participants were sworn to secrecy.  The North Carolina College team beat the Duke medical students 88-44.
events.Name: 1944: A secret game of basketball is played between the Men's basketball team at the North Carolina College for Negroes (now North Carolina Central University) and the Duke University Medical School basketball team.  It was the first mixed-race sporting event in the modern South.  Due to the illegal nature of the game, the game was played on a Sunday morning when most of Durham, including the police would be in church and the participants were sworn to secrecy.  The North Carolina College team beat the Duke medical students 88-44.

Images.caption: Clyde Cox driving a police patrol car.
Images.alt_text: A black police officer is seated in the driver's seat of a police car.
Images.attribution: Photographer: Unknown
Images.citation: Durham Historic Photographic Archive (NCC.0055), North Carolina Collection, Durham County Library, NC

Images.caption: A still shot from "Negro Durham Marches On" shows four black police officers outside of a building.
Images.alt_text: Four black police officers stand together outside. Another officer stands off to the side.
Images.attribution: Source: Negro Durham Marches On
Images.citation: Durham Historic Photographic Archive (NCC.0055), North Carolina Collection, Durham County Library, NC

events.Text: Clyde Cox and Allen Samuel become Durham's first black police officers to provide more police coverage for the Hayti community.  While part of the Durham Police Department, they were not allowed to use the bathroom or water fountains, eat lunch, or change their clothes at the police headquarters.
events.Name: 1944: Clyde Cox and Allen Samuel become Durham's first black police officers to provide more police coverage for the Hayti community.  While part of the Durham Police Department, they were not allowed to use the bathroom or water fountains, eat lunch, or change their clothes at the police headquarters.

events.Text: Private Booker T. Spicely, a black GI stationed at Camp Butner, is killed by a white bus driver Herman Lee Council.  Council ordered Spicely to move to the back of the bus to make room for some white GIs getting on the bus.  When Spicely got off the bus after arguing with Council, Council followed him off the bus and shot him twice before continuing his route.  Council was acquitted of second degree murder by an all-white jury.
events.Name: 1944: Private Booker T. Spicely, a black GI stationed at Camp Butner, is killed by a white bus driver Herman Lee Council.  Council ordered Spicely to move to the back of the bus to make room for some white GIs getting on the bus.  When Spicely got off the bus after arguing with Council, Council followed him off the bus and shot him twice before continuing his route.  Council was acquitted of second degree murder by an all-white jury.

events.Text: Biracial ministers' committee formed to improve "racial cooperation."
events.Name: 1944: Biracial ministers' committee formed to improve "racial cooperation."

events.Text: Durham Committee on Negro Affairs joins organized labor and white liberals in new political bloc formed by Democratic Party activist Les Atkins.
events.Name: 1946: Durham Committee on Negro Affairs joins organized labor and white liberals in new political bloc formed by Democratic Party activist Les Atkins.

events.Text: Motion picture _Negro Durham Marches On_ produced.
events.Name: 1948: Motion picture Negro Durham Marches On produced.

events.Text: Executive Order 9981 issued by President Harry Truman desegregates the US military.
events.Name: 1948: Executive Order 9981 issued by President Harry Truman desegregates the US military.

events.Text: _Ebony_ magazine features Durham's Parrish Street as "Negro Wall Street of America."
events.Name: 1949: Ebony magazine features Durham's Parrish Street as "Negro Wall Street of America."

External Resource Links.Resource Title: Rencher Nicholas “R. N.” Harris, First African American on the City Council and the Durham County Board of Education

Images.caption: R.N. Harris, First Black Elected to Durham City Council. Mr. Harris was elected to the council in 1953. He was also the first black appointed to the school board, in 1958. The man in the center back of the picture in the light suit is George Watts Carr Jr.
Images.alt_text: A group of men hold their hands on a book and raise their other hands in the motion of taking an oath.
Images.attribution: Photographer: Unknown
Images.citation: Durham Historic Photographic Archive (NCC.0055), North Carolina Collection, Durham County Library, NC

events.Text: Rencher N. Harris becomes first African-American elected to the Durham City Council.
events.Name: 1953: Rencher N. Harris becomes first African-American elected to the Durham City Council.

External Resource Links.Resource Title: Brown v. Board of Education in PBS' The Supreme Court

events.Text: _Brown v. Board of Education_ Supreme Court decision overturns separate-but-equal principle.  This landmark case established racially segregated schools as unconstitutional.
events.Headline: Brown v. Board of Education overturns separate-but-equal
events.Name: 1954: Brown v. Board of Education overturns separate-but-equal

events.Text: The Montgomery Bus Boycott brings Martin Luther King, Jr., to prominence.  The campaign lasted from December 5, 1955, the Monday after Rosa Parks was arrested for refusing to give up her seat to a white person, to December 20, 1956 when Browder v. Gayle went into effect.  Browder v. Gayle declared that bus segregation was unconstitutional.
events.Headline: Montgomery Bus Boycott
events.Name: 1955: Montgomery Bus Boycott

events.Text: 14-year-old Emmett Till murdered in Mississippi for whistling at a white woman.
events.Name: 1955: 14-year-old Emmett Till murdered in Mississippi for whistling at a white woman.

Images.caption: On October 15, 1956, Martin Luther King, Jr., spoke at Hillside High School. A young Baptist minister, King was receiving his first national attention for guiding a boycott of segregated city buses in Montgomery, Alabama. Invited by the Durham Business and Professional Chain as part of its Trade Week festivity, King told his audience, "Doors will be open to you now that were never open in the past. … Be ready for opportunities."
Images.alt_text: Dr. Martin Luther King stands behind a podium. Two other black men can be seen seated behind him.
Images.attribution: Photographer: Jim Sparks, Durham Herald Sun.
Images.citation: Durham Civil Rights Heritage Project Collection (NCC.0040), North Carolina Collection, Durham County Library, NC

events.Text: Martin Luther King, Jr., attends Durham Business and Professional Chain Trade Week, speaks at Hillside High School.  Invited by the Durham Business and Professional Chain as part of its Trade Week festivity, King told his audience, "Doors will be open to you now that were never open in the past. … Be ready for opportunities."  This was King's first visit to Durham.
events.Name: 1956: Martin Luther King, Jr., attends Durham Business and Professional Chain Trade Week, speaks at Hillside High School.  Invited by the Durham Business and Professional Chain as part of its Trade Week festivity, King told his audience, "Doors will be open to you now that were never open in the past. … Be ready for opportunities."  This was King's first visit to Durham.

events.Text: Durham Interdenominational Ministers Alliance passes a resolution for "a community free of discrimination and segregation"
events.Name: 1957: Durham Interdenominational Ministers Alliance passes a resolution for "a community free of discrimination and segregation"

Images.caption: The Royal Ice Cream strikers pray before going to court. Participants included Mary Clyburn, Virginia Williams, Rev. Douglas E. Moore, Vivian Jones, Jesse Gray, Claude Glenn, and Melvin H. Willis.  "It was exciting, because we went where we dared not to go. I wasn't frightened or anything of that sort because either way, we could have made history. If he had served us ice cream, he would have made history. But, by refusing to, I guess we made history!" -Virginia Williams, Royal Ice Cream Protester, 2003 Interview
Images.alt_text: Five black men and women kneel in prayer before a black minister.
Images.attribution: Source: Virginia Williams
Images.citation: Durham Civil Rights Heritage Project Collection (NCC.0040), North Carolina Collection, Durham County Library, NC

events.Text: Sit-in occurs at Royal Ice Cream parlor.  Seven protesters, led by Reverend Douglas Moore entered Royal Ice Cream through the colored entrance, sat down in the white section, and asked to be served.  The group was refused and asked to leave.  When they refused to leave, they were arrested, charged with trespassing, and fined $10.
events.Headline: Royal Ice Cream Sit In
events.Name: 1957: Royal Ice Cream Sit In

events.Text: Black teachers admitted to summer institute at Duke University.
events.Name: 1957: Black teachers admitted to summer institute at Duke University.

events.Text: Parents of Joycelyn McKissick and Elaine Richardson sue for their daughters' reassignment to Durham High School.
events.Name: 1957: Parents of Joycelyn McKissick and Elaine Richardson sue for their daughters' reassignment to Durham High School.

External Resource Links.Source (Shortform): Durham Civil and Human Rights Map

events.Text: Durham Bulls have first black players, Bubba Morton and Ted Richardson.  Demonstrators attempt to integrate Durham Athletic Park seating on opening night by flooding the white-only entrance.  The demonstrators were denied entry through the entrance and were offered segregated seating and were eventually escorted off the premises.
events.Name: 1957: Durham Bulls have first black players, Bubba Morton and Ted Richardson.  Demonstrators attempt to integrate Durham Athletic Park seating on opening night by flooding the white-only entrance.  The demonstrators were denied entry through the entrance and were offered segregated seating and were eventually escorted off the premises.

events.Text: City tennis courts integrated.
events.Name: 1957: City tennis courts integrated.

events.Text: Mayor E. J. (Mutt) Evans forms Committee on Human Relations to address strained race relations.
events.Name: 1957: Mayor E. J. (Mutt) Evans forms Committee on Human Relations to address strained race relations.

events.Text: The Little Rock Nine were a group of African-American high school students enrolled in Little Rock Central High School.  The decision to integrate the school was opposed by Arkansas Governor Orval Faubus who deployed the National Guard to prevent the Little Rock Nine from attending the segregated school.  President Eisenhower issued Executive Order 10730 which ordered U.S. Army troops and federalized the Arkansas National Guard to enforce school desegregation in Little Rock, Arkansas.
events.Headline: National Guard called in to help the Little Rock Nine integrate Little Rock Central High School
events.Name: 1957: National Guard called in to help the Little Rock Nine integrate Little Rock Central High School

events.Text: Southern Christian Leadership Conference (SCLC) founded with Martin Luther King, Jr. as president. The concepts of nonviolent mass action, affiliation with local community organization, and being a movement open to all were cornerstones of the group's strategy.
events.Name: 1957: Southern Christian Leadership Conference (SCLC) founded with Martin Luther King, Jr. as president. The concepts of nonviolent mass action, affiliation with local community organization, and being a movement open to all were cornerstones of the group's strategy.

events.Text: Rencher N. Harris becomes the first black man on Durham city Board of Education.
events.Name: 1958: Rencher N. Harris becomes the first black man on Durham city Board of Education.

External Resource Links.Resource Title: Hayti’s first fire company lacked resources, not courage

events.Text: Durham Fire Station No. 4 opens in Hayti.  It was the first Durham fire station to have an all African-American crew salaried by the city.
events.Name: 1958: Durham Fire Station No. 4 opens in Hayti.  It was the first Durham fire station to have an all African-American crew salaried by the city.

External Resource Links.Resource Title: Andree McKissick and Henry Vickers Integrate Carr Junior High

Images.caption: Durham lawyer Floyd B. McKissick and his wife, Evelyn, escort their daughter, Andree, and Henry Vickers to their first day of classes at Carr Junior High School, Sept. 2, 1959.
Images.alt_text: From left to right: Henry Vickers, Floyd McKissick, Andree McKissick, and Evelyn McKissick walk on a sidewalk outside Carr Junior High School.
Images.attribution: Photographer: Jim Sparks, Durham Herald Sun.
Images.citation: Durham Civil Rights Heritage Project Collection (NCC.0040), North Carolina Collection, Durham County Library, NC

events.Text: City school board allows reassignment of eight black pupils to previously all-white schools.  Anita Brame and Lucy Jones are first to integrate, at Brogden Junior High.  Andree McKissick and Henry Vickers integrate Carr Junior High.  Joycelyn McKissick integrates Durham High School.
events.Headline: Durham schools integrate
events.Name: 1959: Durham schools integrate

events.Text: Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee (SNCC) founded at Shaw University, Raleigh, North Carolina.
events.Name: 1960: Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee (SNCC) founded at Shaw University, Raleigh, North Carolina.

events.Text: The Greensboro Four, students at North Carolina A&T State University conducted a sit-in at the "whites only" Woolworth lunch counter in Greensboro, North Carolina.  Their actions inspired a sit-in movement across the United States to desegregate Woolworth.
events.Headline: The Greensboro Four conduct a sit-in at the "whites only" lunch counter at Woolworth
events.Name: 1960: The Greensboro Four conduct a sit-in at the "whites only" lunch counter at Woolworth

External Resource Links.Resource Title: Lawyers Who Brought Suit to Integrate Durham Schools

Images.caption: Conrad Pearson, Hugh Thompson, Floyd McKissick, William G. Marsh, John H. Wheeler, Durham Schools suit lawyers.
Images.alt_text: Five black men stand and look at a piece of paper.
Images.attribution: Photographer: Unknown
Images.citation: Durham Historic Photographic Archive (NCC.0055), North Carolina Collection, Durham County Library, NC

events.Text: Durham attorneys bring lawsuit against the Durham City Board of Education to integrate Durham public schools.  For the 1959-1960 school year, the African-American community submitted 225 reassignment requests but only 8 were approved.  Attorneys Conrad Pearson, Hugh Thompson, Floyd McKissick, William G. Marsh, and John H. Wheeler brought several cases against the Board of Education to completely integrate schools.
events.Name: 1960: Durham attorneys bring lawsuit against the Durham City Board of Education to integrate Durham public schools.  For the 1959-1960 school year, the African-American community submitted 225 reassignment requests but only 8 were approved.  Attorneys Conrad Pearson, Hugh Thompson, Floyd McKissick, William G. Marsh, and John H. Wheeler brought several cases against the Board of Education to completely integrate schools.

Images.caption: Flanked by Durham minister Douglas Moore, left, and civil rights activist Rev. Ralph Abernathy, Martin Luther King, Jr., walks along Main Street in Durham for a visit to the closed Woolworth's lunch counter. The man at the far right is unidentified.
Images.alt_text: From left to right: Reverend Douglas Moore, Reverend Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., Reverend Ralph Abernathy, and an unidentified man walk outside in Durham.
Images.attribution: Photographer: Jim Thornton, Durham Herald Sun
Images.citation: Durham Civil Rights Heritage Project Collection (NCC.0040), North Carolina Collection, Durham County Library, NC

Images.caption: Martin Luther King Jr. speaks at White Rock Baptist Church February 16, 1960. His appearance drew a standing-room-only crowd estimated at 1,200, who responded by collecting money for future demonstration expenses.
Images.alt_text: Dr. Martin Luther King preaching in a church. The organ and choir are visible behind him.
Images.attribution: Photographer: Harold Moore, Durham Herald Sun.
Images.citation: Durham Civil Rights Heritage Project Collection (NCC.0040), North Carolina Collection, Durham County Library, NC

Images.caption: Martin Luther King, Jr., center, visits the Woolworth's lunch counter in downtown Durham, February 16, 1960. The store had closed the counter after sit-in demonstrations there the previous week. With King are civil rights activist Rev. Ralph Abernathy at left; Rev. Douglas Moore, who led Durham's first sit-in, in 1957 at the Royal Ice Cream Company, right of King; and an unidentified man at far right.
Images.alt_text: From left to right: Reverend Ralph Abernathy, Dr. Martin Luther King, Reverend Douglas Moore and an unidentified black man standing in a store.
Images.attribution: Photographer: Jim Thornton, Durham Herald Sun.
Images.citation: Durham Civil Rights Heritage Project Collection (NCC.0040), North Carolina Collection, Durham County Library, NC

events.Text: A week after sit-ins began in Durham, Martin Luther King, Jr., and Ralph Abernathy visited Durham to speak to a standing-room only audience at White Rock Baptist Church.  Talking to the standing-room only crowd that filled the church, he counseled the crowd, “Let us not fear going to jail if the officials threaten to arrest us for standing up for our rights…Maybe it will take this willingness to stay in jail to arouse the dozing conscience of our nation.”
events.Headline: Martin Luther King Jr. visits Durham and speaks at White Rock Baptist Church
events.Event Page: Martin Luther King, Jr.'s Visits to Durham, 1956–1964
events.Name: 1960: Martin Luther King Jr. visits Durham and speaks at White Rock Baptist Church

External Resource Links.Resource Title: Lunch Counter Sit In at Woolworth Five & Dime
External Resource Links.Source (Shortform): Durham Civil and Human Rights Map

events.Text: Four days after the Greensboro sit-ins began, seventeen students from North Carolina College staged sit-ins at lunch counters at Woolworth, Kress, and Walgreen's.  They were accompanied by several white students from Duke University who pledged to occupy seats until the blacks were served.  The sit-ins led to the lunch counters being "closed temporarily in the interest of public safety.”
events.Name: 1960: Four days after the Greensboro sit-ins began, seventeen students from North Carolina College staged sit-ins at lunch counters at Woolworth, Kress, and Walgreen's.  They were accompanied by several white students from Duke University who pledged to occupy seats until the blacks were served.  The sit-ins led to the lunch counters being "closed temporarily in the interest of public safety.”

events.Text: CORE and SNCC sends integrated Freedom Rider groups to protest segregation on southern buses which was declared unconstitutional under the Supreme Court ruling in _Morgan v. Virginia_ and _Boynton v. Virginia._ Southern local and state police viewed the Freedom Riders as criminals and arrested them in some locations.  The police in Birmingham, Alabama collaborated with the KKK and allowed white mobs to attack Freedom Riders and burn the bus.
events.Name: 1961: CORE and SNCC sends integrated Freedom Rider groups to protest segregation on southern buses which was declared unconstitutional under the Supreme Court ruling in Morgan v. Virginia and Boynton v. Virginia. Southern local and state police viewed the Freedom Riders as criminals and arrested them in some locations.  The police in Birmingham, Alabama collaborated with the KKK and allowed white mobs to attack Freedom Riders and burn the bus.

events.Text: Duke University desegregates graduate and professional schools.
events.Name: 1961: Duke University desegregates graduate and professional schools.

Images.caption: A "round-robin" demonstrator asks to buy a ticket to the Carolina Theatre and gets a refusal at the box office. Once turned away, protesters went to the end of the line and waited their turns to try again.
Images.alt_text: A black woman stands at a ticket counter speaking to a white woman ticket seller. A long line of black people is formed behind her.
Images.attribution: Photographer: Jim Sparks, Durham Herald Sun.
Images.citation: Durham Civil Rights Heritage Project Collection (NCC.0040), North Carolina Collection, Durham County Library, NC

Images.caption: A line of "round-robin" protesters extends along Manning Place from the Carolina Theatre box office past city hall (now Durham Arts Council Building) March 14, 1962.
Images.alt_text: A long line of black people formed along a sidewalk outside the Carolina Theatre.
Images.attribution: Photographer: Jim Sparks, Durham Herald Sun.
Images.citation: Durham Civil Rights Heritage Project Collection (NCC.0040), North Carolina Collection, Durham County Library, NC

Images.caption: The line of "round-robin" demonstrators stretches from the Carolina Theatre box office west along Manning Place, March 15, 1962. Denied tickets, marchers would return to the end of the line and wait for another turn.
Images.alt_text: A long line of black people outside the Carolina Theatre.
Images.attribution: Photographer: Jim Sparks, Durham Herald Sun.
Images.citation: Durham Civil Rights Heritage Project Collection (NCC.0040), North Carolina Collection, Durham County Library, NC

events.Text: Protesters begin picketing Durham movie theaters including the Carolina Theatre.  When the management at the Carolina Theatre refused to desegregate, protesters began a rolling line protest that lasted for months.  When a protester approached the ticket window and was refused admittance to the white section of the theater, he or she went to the back of the line to try again.  Movie theaters desegregated in 1963.
events.Headline: Rolling line protests to desegregate theaters in Durham
events.Name: 1961: Rolling line protests to desegregate theaters in Durham

events.Text: NAACP head Roy Wilkins and CORE head James Farmer visit, speak at St. Joseph's AME Church.
events.Name: 1962: NAACP head Roy Wilkins and CORE head James Farmer visit, speak at St. Joseph's AME Church.

events.Text: Attorney Floyd McKissick organizes Congress of Racial Equality chapter.
events.Name: 1962: Attorney Floyd McKissick organizes Congress of Racial Equality chapter.

External Resource Links.Resource Title: Civil Rights Demonstration at Howard Johnson’s Restaurant

Images.caption: A crowd estimated at 500 people demonstrates against segregation at Howard Johnson's Restaurant on the Durham-Chapel Hill Boulevard on August 12, 1962. Sunday afternoon protests at the restaurant went on for almost a year, until mass demonstrations in May 1963 led to integration of most eating establishments in Durham.
Images.alt_text: A large group of people gather along the side of a highway outside a Howard Johnson's.
Images.attribution: Photographer: Harold Moore, Durham Herald Sun.
Images.citation: Durham Civil Rights Heritage Project Collection (NCC.0040), North Carolina Collection, Durham County Library, NC

Images.caption: Roy Wilkins (left), executive director of the NAACP, joins Durham Attorney Floyd McKissick and James Farmer (right), national director of the Congress of Racial Equality, to protest segregation at Durham's Howard Johnson's Restaurant on August 12, 1962.
Images.alt_text: From left to right: Roy Wilkins, Floyd McKissick, and James Farmer in suits standing outside. A fourth man is standing behind them with his back turned.
Images.attribution: Photographer: Harold Moore, Durham Herald Sun.
Images.citation: Durham Civil Rights Heritage Project Collection (NCC.0040), North Carolina Collection, Durham County Library, NC

events.Text: Demonstrations begin at the Chapel Hill Boulevard Howard Johnson's Restaurant.  The goal of these protests was to integrate restaurants in Durham.
events.Headline: Demonstrations at Howard Johnson's begin the struggle to integrate restaurants in Durham
events.Name: 1962: Demonstrations at Howard Johnson's begin the struggle to integrate restaurants in Durham

events.Text: U.S. troops deployed to Oxford, Mississippi, after rioting follows James Meredith's matriculation at University of Mississippi law school.
events.Name: 1962: U.S. troops deployed to Oxford, Mississippi, after rioting follows James Meredith's matriculation at University of Mississippi law school.

events.Text: NAACP Mississippi field secretary Medgar Evers murdered in Jackson, Mississippi.
events.Name: 1963: NAACP Mississippi field secretary Medgar Evers murdered in Jackson, Mississippi.

events.Text: The Birmingham Movement was organized by SCLC to bring attention integration efforts in Birmingham, Alabama.  Nonviolent civil rights protesters were met with police dogs and fire hoses.  These nonviolent protests brought the fight for integration into the national spotlight.
events.Name: 1963: The Birmingham Movement was organized by SCLC to bring attention integration efforts in Birmingham, Alabama.  Nonviolent civil rights protesters were met with police dogs and fire hoses.  These nonviolent protests brought the fight for integration into the national spotlight.

events.Text: Four girls were killed by a bomb planted by the Ku Klux Klan at the 16th Street Baptist Church in Birmingham, Alabama.
events.Name: 1963: Four girls were killed by a bomb planted by the Ku Klux Klan at the 16th Street Baptist Church in Birmingham, Alabama.

External Resource Links.Resource Title: March on Washington for Jobs and Freedom

events.Text: Around 250,000 people gathered in Washington, D.C. to march to advocate for civil and economic right for African-Americans.  During the march, Martin Luther King, Jr. delivered his "I Have a Dream" speech in front of the Lincoln Memorial.
events.Name: 1963: Around 250,000 people gathered in Washington, D.C. to march to advocate for civil and economic right for African-Americans.  During the march, Martin Luther King, Jr. delivered his "I Have a Dream" speech in front of the Lincoln Memorial.

Images.caption: Students from North Carolina College (now North Carolina Central University) and Hillside High School demonstrate at city hall on May 18, 1963. Theirs was one of several simultaneous protests in Durham, which continued for four days and led to 850 arrests.
Images.alt_text: A large group of black people stand together, many with their arms in the air. One person holds a sign that says "You have the freedom to vote."
Images.attribution: Photographer: Harold Moore, Durham Herald Sun.
Images.citation: Durham Civil Rights Heritage Project Collection (NCC.0040), North Carolina Collection, Durham County Library, NC

events.Text: 30-day mass-demonstration campaign for integrating of public facilities; 130 arrests on first night.
events.Name: 1963: 30-day mass-demonstration campaign for integrating of public facilities; 130 arrests on first night.

External Resource Links.Resource Title: R. Wensell “Wense” Grabarek, City Councilman and Mayor of Durham

events.Text: Mayor Wense Grabarek meets protest rally, forms Durham Interim Committee on race relations.
events.Name: 1963: Mayor Wense Grabarek meets protest rally, forms Durham Interim Committee on race relations.

events.Text: Durham movie theaters agree to integration.
events.Name: 1963: Durham movie theaters agree to integration.

events.Text: Public swimming pools and libraries integrate.
events.Name: 1963: Public swimming pools and libraries integrate.

events.Text: Chamber of Commerce and Jaycees open membership to blacks.
events.Name: 1963: Chamber of Commerce and Jaycees open membership to blacks.

events.Text: Federal court orders Durham city schools to adopt freedom-of-choice desegregation plan; pace of school integration accelerates.
events.Name: 1963: Federal court orders Durham city schools to adopt freedom-of-choice desegregation plan; pace of school integration accelerates.

events.Text: Most Durham hotels and restaurants integrate.
events.Name: 1963: Most Durham hotels and restaurants integrate.

events.Text: Durham County Citizens Council formed to oppose integration.
events.Name: 1963: Durham County Citizens Council formed to oppose integration.

events.Text: Duke University desegregates undergraduate schools.
events.Name: 1963: Duke University desegregates undergraduate schools.

Images.caption: Malcolm X (born Malcolm Little), a gifted orator and advocate for radical political action to advance black interests, appeared in Page’s Auditorium on Roxboro Street on April 18, 1963. He debated Durham resident Floyd McKissick, an NAACP lawyer and civil rights activist, before a standing-room-only crowd, roughly 75 percent black and many of whom were students. Originally scheduled at W. D. Hill Recreation Center, the program was moved after city officials canceled the reservation on the grounds that the Black Muslims were not a religious group, as they had stated. McKissick declared that the city “stomped on the first amendment” to the Constitution when it denied the use of the hall for the debate.
Images.alt_text: Malcolm X standing behind a podium.
Images.attribution: Photographer: Harold Moore, Durham Herald Sun
Images.citation: Durham Civil Rights Heritage Project Collection (NCC.0040), North Carolina Collection, Durham County Library, NC

events.Text: Malcolm X debates local NAACP attorney and civil rights activist Floyd McKissick in front of a standing room only crowd at the Page Auditorium.
events.Name: 1963: Malcolm X debates local NAACP attorney and civil rights activist Floyd McKissick in front of a standing room only crowd at the Page Auditorium.

events.Text: Black leaders petition Durham County schools to accept pupil reassignments.
events.Name: 1963: Black leaders petition Durham County schools to accept pupil reassignments.

events.Text: Industrial Education Center integrates programs in retail distribution and marketing.
events.Name: 1963: Industrial Education Center integrates programs in retail distribution and marketing.

events.Text: 24th Amendment outlaws poll taxes for national elections.
events.Name: 1964: 24th Amendment outlaws poll taxes for national elections.

events.Text: The Organization of Afro-American Unity was created by Malcolm X to fight for the human rights of African-Americans and promote cooperation between Africans and people of African descent in the Americas.
events.Name: 1964: The Organization of Afro-American Unity was created by Malcolm X to fight for the human rights of African-Americans and promote cooperation between Africans and people of African descent in the Americas.

External Resource Links.Resource Title: Murders of Chaney, Goodman, and Schwerner

events.Text: Freedom Summer volunteers James Chaney, Andrew Goodman, and Michael Schwerner were murdered by members of the Ku Klux Klan in Neshoba County, Mississippi.
events.Name: 1964: Freedom Summer volunteers James Chaney, Andrew Goodman, and Michael Schwerner were murdered by members of the Ku Klux Klan in Neshoba County, Mississippi.

events.Text: The Civil Rights Act of 1964 outlaws discrimination based on race, color, religion, sex, or national origin by employers and in public accommodations.
events.Headline: The Civil Rights Act of 1964
events.Name: 1964: The Civil Rights Act of 1964

events.Text: The Mississippi Summer Project, also known as Freedom Summer, organized a voter registration drive to register African-Americans in Mississippi to vote.
events.Name: 1964: The Mississippi Summer Project, also known as Freedom Summer, organized a voter registration drive to register African-Americans in Mississippi to vote.

Images.caption: Martin Luther King, Jr., addresses the Southern Political Science Association at Durham's Jack Tar Hotel November 13, 1964. By that time, King was the best-known leader of and spokesman for the Civil Rights Movement, his efforts rewarded with the 1964 Nobel Peace Prize.
Images.alt_text: Dr. Martin Luther King standing behind a podium at the Jack Tar Hotel.
Images.attribution: Photographer: Harold Moore, Durham Herald Sun.
Images.citation: Durham Civil Rights Heritage Project Collection (NCC.0040), North Carolina Collection, Durham County Library, NC

events.Text: Martin Luther King visits Durham and speaks at the Jack Tar Hotel.
events.Name: 1964: Martin Luther King visits Durham and speaks at the Jack Tar Hotel.

events.Text: Durham Interim Committee replaced by Committee on Community Relations.
events.Name: 1964: Durham Interim Committee replaced by Committee on Community Relations.

events.Text: Malcolm X is assassinated in New York City.
events.Name: 1965: Malcolm X is assassinated in New York City.

events.Text: Voting Rights Act abolishes literacy tests and other practices to obstruct minority voting.
events.Headline: Voting Rights Act of 1965
events.Name: 1965: Voting Rights Act of 1965

events.Text: Executive Order 11246 establishes requirements for non-discriminatory practices in hiring and employment on the part of U.S. government contractors.
events.Name: 1965: Executive Order 11246 establishes requirements for non-discriminatory practices in hiring and employment on the part of U.S. government contractors.

events.Text: The Selma to Montgomery March was organized as a nonviolent protest by African-Americans who wanted to exercise the right to vote by marching 54 miles from Selma, Alabama to the state capital Montgomery.  The first march, known as "Bloody Sunday," was violently suppressed by Alabama State Troopers and Dallas County Police Officers.  Ten days later, the protesters successfully began their march from Selma to Montgomery.
events.Headline: The Selma to Montgomery March is violently suppressed by Alabama police
events.Name: 1965: The Selma to Montgomery March is violently suppressed by Alabama police

events.Text: The Watts Riots broke out in Los Angeles, California due to tensions between the police and African-Americans living in the highly impoverished Watts neighborhood.  The riot was a result of longstanding issues including high unemployment, substandard housing, and inadequate schooling for the citizens of Watts.
events.Name: 1965: The Watts Riots broke out in Los Angeles, California due to tensions between the police and African-Americans living in the highly impoverished Watts neighborhood.  The riot was a result of longstanding issues including high unemployment, substandard housing, and inadequate schooling for the citizens of Watts.

events.Text: Durham County schools begin desegregation under freedom-of-choice plan.
events.Name: 1965: Durham County schools begin desegregation under freedom-of-choice plan.

Images.caption: 250 employees, students, and faculty protest in front of the Duke Administration Building on April 19, 1967.
Images.alt_text: A line of protesters with signs marching on Duke's campus. In the foreground are African-American women and in the background are some white male students.
Images.attribution: Photographer: Bill Boyarsky
Images.citation: Durham Civil Rights Heritage Project Collection (NCC.0040), North Carolina Collection, Durham County Library, NC

Images.caption: Employees, students, and faculty protest in front of the Duke Administration Building on April 19, 1967.
Images.alt_text: A line of protesters carrying signs on Duke's campus.
Images.attribution: Photographer: Bill Boyarsky
Images.citation: Durham Civil Rights Heritage Project Collection (NCC.0040), North Carolina Collection, Durham County Library, NC

Images.caption: Oliver Harvey and unidentified student distribute literature about employee issues in April 1967.
Images.alt_text: Two white men stand at an information table. A white male student and Oliver Harvey are behind the table.
Images.attribution: Photographer: Bill Boyarsky
Images.citation: Durham Civil Rights Heritage Project Collection (NCC.0040), North Carolina Collection, Durham County Library, NC

events.Text: Local 77 labor union is created at Duke University to advocate for improved working conditions, increase in wages, and health benefits for working class workers at Duke, many of whom were African-American.
events.Name: 1965: Local 77 labor union is created at Duke University to advocate for improved working conditions, increase in wages, and health benefits for working class workers at Duke, many of whom were African-American.

events.Text: SNCC leader Stokely Carmichael coins the phrase "Black Power."  Carmichael saw the concept of "Black Power" as a means of solidarity between individuals within the movement.
events.Name: 1966: SNCC leader Stokely Carmichael coins the phrase "Black Power."  Carmichael saw the concept of "Black Power" as a means of solidarity between individuals within the movement.

events.Text: Black Panthers founded in Oakland, California by Bobby Seale and Huey Newton.
events.Name: 1966: Black Panthers founded in Oakland, California by Bobby Seale and Huey Newton.

events.Text: Activist Howard Fuller forms United Organizations for Community Improvement to encourage black political participation.
events.Name: 1966: Activist Howard Fuller forms United Organizations for Community Improvement to encourage black political participation.

events.Text: Demonstrations held for city schools to begin Headstart and Youth Corps.
events.Name: 1966: Demonstrations held for city schools to begin Headstart and Youth Corps.

events.Text: "The Long, Hot Summer" was a series of race riots that erupted across the United States, stemming from racial inequality, poverty, and unemployment.  The largest and most deadly riots occurred in Detroit, Michigan and Newark, New Jersey.
events.Name: 1967: "The Long, Hot Summer" was a series of race riots that erupted across the United States, stemming from racial inequality, poverty, and unemployment.  The largest and most deadly riots occurred in Detroit, Michigan and Newark, New Jersey.

events.Text: Supreme Court case _Loving v. Virginia_ rules that laws banning interracial marriage violate the Fourteenth Amendment.
events.Name: 1967: Supreme Court case Loving v. Virginia rules that laws banning interracial marriage violate the Fourteenth Amendment.

events.Text: Headstart and Youth Corps instituted in city schools.
events.Name: 1967: Headstart and Youth Corps instituted in city schools.

Images.caption: Howard Fuller (on wall) leads demonstrators past National Guardsmen along Peabody Street on their way to a civil rights rally in front of City Hall, in this file photo from July 20, 1967.
Images.alt_text: A group of black people walking outside. Howard Fuller stands on a wall. Three white male National Guard soldiers armed with guns with bayonets stand and watch them.
Images.attribution: Photographer: Harold Moore, Durham Herald Sun.
Images.citation: Durham Civil Rights Heritage Project Collection (NCC.0040), North Carolina Collection, Durham County Library, NC

Images.caption: Organizers Howard Fuller (left) and Ben Ruffin were major figures in late-1960s actions that often focused on gaining black representation on Durham 's policy-making agencies and protesting alleged inequities in managing the city's public housing.
Images.alt_text: Howard Fuller looks over his shoulder while standing with some other men. Other people can be seen in the background.
Images.attribution: Photographer: Harold Moore, Durham Herald Sun.
Images.citation: Durham Civil Rights Heritage Project Collection (NCC.0040), North Carolina Collection, Durham County Library, NC

events.Text: Demonstrations over housing conditions turn violent; Mayor Wense Grabarek summons National Guard to enforce order.
events.Name: 1967: Demonstrations over housing conditions turn violent; Mayor Wense Grabarek summons National Guard to enforce order.

events.Text: Asa Spaulding becomes the first black commissioner on the Durham Board of County Commissioners.
events.Name: 1967: Asa Spaulding becomes the first black commissioner on the Durham Board of County Commissioners.

Images.caption: Members of National Guard rest in Holt School. They were called in after the death of Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. Photo taken April 7, 1968.
Images.alt_text: Three white, armed National Guard soldiers seated on a bench. One of them is reading a newspaper.
Images.attribution: Photographer: Harold Moore, Durham Herald Sun.
Images.citation: Durham Civil Rights Heritage Project Collection (NCC.0040), North Carolina Collection, Durham County Library, NC

Images.caption: Demonstrators rally at Durham City Hall at the end of a march from Fayetteville Street on April 5, 1968, the morning after Martin Luther King's assassination in Memphis. While the march was peaceful, Durham would erupt in arson the following day, leading city officials to call out the National Guard and impose a curfew to curb further violence and restore order in town.
Images.alt_text: A large crowd of people gathered outside of city hall.
Images.attribution: Photographer: Harold Moore, Durham Herald Sun.
Images.citation: Durham Civil Rights Heritage Project Collection (NCC.0040), North Carolina Collection, Durham County Library, NC

events.Text: The day following the assassination of Martin Luther King Jr., protestors march from Fayetteville Street to City Hall in peaceful protest.  The next night, arsonists set numerous fires around the city, leading to a mobilization of the National Guard and curfew.
events.Headline: Protests, arson, and curfew follow Martin Luther King Jr.'s assassination
events.Name: 1968: Protests, arson, and curfew follow Martin Luther King Jr.'s assassination

Images.caption: Heavy police guard accompanies students on the second day of protest in response to the killings at South Carolina State College in Orangeburg , S.C.
Images.alt_text: A large group of people in the street. Most people in the image are police in riot gear with their backs to the camera.
Images.attribution: Photographer: Bill Boyarsky
Images.citation: Durham Civil Rights Heritage Project Collection (NCC.0040), North Carolina Collection, Durham County Library, NC

Images.caption: Police downtown during Orangeburg sympathy protest.
Images.alt_text: Two police officers in riot gear stand outside a storefront.
Images.attribution: Photographer: Bill Boyarsky
Images.citation: Durham Civil Rights Heritage Project Collection (NCC.0040), North Carolina Collection, Durham County Library, NC

Images.caption: Student protesters downtown during Orangeburg sympathy protest.
Images.alt_text: A group of African-American protesters. One person holds a sign that says "End Police Brutality."
Images.attribution: Photographer: Bill Boyarsky
Images.citation: Durham Civil Rights Heritage Project Collection (NCC.0040), North Carolina Collection, Durham County Library, NC

events.Text: Protesters in Durham march in sympathy with the victims of the Orangeburg Massacre.
events.Name: 1968: Protesters in Durham march in sympathy with the victims of the Orangeburg Massacre.

events.Text: Howard Clement forms Black Solidarity Committee for Community Improvement.
events.Name: 1968: Howard Clement forms Black Solidarity Committee for Community Improvement.

External Resource Links.Resource Title: Black Solidarity Committee’s Black Christmas Parade

Images.caption: William McBroom plays "Black Santa" for the Selective Buying Campaign's alternative Christmas parade, November 29, 1968.
Images.alt_text: An African-American man dressed as Santa Claus sits atop a float. Numerous people are gathered around him.
Images.attribution: Photographer: Harold Moore, Durham Herald Sun.
Images.citation: Durham Civil Rights Heritage Project Collection (NCC.0040), North Carolina Collection, Durham County Library, NC

Images.caption: N.C. Mutual executive R. Kelly Bryant, Jr., tosses lollipops, and Santa Claus (William McBroom) receives onlookers' cheers during a "Black Christmas" parade, November 29, 1968. Sponsored by the Black Solidarity Committee for Community Improvement as part of its boycott of certain white-owned businesses, the parade was held on Fayetteville Street at the same time as the Durham Merchants Association's traditional parade downtown.
Images.alt_text: A parade with mostly African-American people watching and a float with a black man dressed as Santa Claus.
Images.attribution: Photographer: Harold Moore, Durham Herald Sun.
Images.citation: Durham Civil Rights Heritage Project Collection (NCC.0040), North Carolina Collection, Durham County Library, NC

Images.caption: The Selective Buying Campaign began in July 1968, when an organization called the Black Solidarity Committee for Community Improvement issued a 15-page memorandum to the Durham Chamber of Commerce and Merchants Association, demanding changes in welfare, housing, and employment policies in the city. The boycott lasted until February 16, 1969.
Images.alt_text: A flyer published by the Black Solidarity Committee for Community Improvement asking for support for the "Selective Buying Campaign."
Images.attribution: Source: Black Solidarity Committee for Community Improvement
Images.citation: Durham Civil Rights Heritage Project Collection (NCC.0040), North Carolina Collection, Durham County Library, NC

events.Text: Solidarity Committee begins selective merchant boycott, lasting through the Christmas season.
events.Headline: Black Solidarity Committee for Community Improvement begins a selective merchant boycott in Durham
events.Name: 1968: Black Solidarity Committee for Community Improvement begins a selective merchant boycott in Durham

External Resource Links.Resource Title: Student Activism at Duke University - Silent Vigil

Images.caption: Duke students' silent vigil after assassination of Martin Luther King, Jr.
Images.alt_text: A large crowd gathered on Duke's campus. In the foreground one white man stands with a sign that says "Silent Vigil in Memory of Martin Luther King."
Images.attribution: Photographer: Bill Boyarsky
Images.citation: Durham Civil Rights Heritage Project Collection (NCC.0040), North Carolina Collection, Durham County Library, NC

Images.caption: Duke students and faculty at campus event after assassination of Martin Luther King, Jr.
Images.alt_text: A group of white people stand with arms crossed, holding hands and appear to be singing.
Images.attribution: Photographer: Bill Boyarsky
Images.citation: Jack Preiss, Durham Civil Rights Heritage Project Collection (NCC.0040), North Carolina Collection, Durham County Library, NC

Images.caption: Students sit silently in order lines during Duke student's silent vigil.
Images.alt_text: A large crowd of people sit on a lawn near Duke Chapel.
Images.attribution: Photographer: Bill Boyarsky
Images.citation: Jack Preiss, Durham Civil Rights Heritage Project Collection (NCC.0040), North Carolina Collection, Durham County Library, NC

events.Text: After Martin Luther King Jr.'s assassination, students at Duke University hold a silent vigil to demand collective bargaining for the campus' Local 77 union as well advocate against racial discrimination on campus and in Durham.
events.Headline: Duke University holds a silent vigil in reaction to Martin Luther King Jr.'s assassination
events.Name: 1968: Duke University holds a silent vigil in reaction to Martin Luther King Jr.'s assassination

Images.caption: A young anti-Wallace protester makes his voice heard at Durham 's Wallace-for-president rally.
Images.alt_text: Close-up of an African-American man standing in a crowd with his arm raised in the air.
Images.attribution: Photographer: Bill Boyarsky
Images.citation: Durham Civil Rights Heritage Project Collection (NCC.0040), North Carolina Collection, Durham County Library, NC

Images.caption: Supporters and opponents of former Alabama governor George Wallace clash at a 1968 Wallace-for-President rally at Durham police headquarters.
Images.alt_text: A large crowd of people with signs. Some police officers in riot gear visible.
Images.attribution: Photographer: Bill Boyarsky
Images.citation: Durham Civil Rights Heritage Project Collection (NCC.0040), North Carolina Collection, Durham County Library, NC

Images.caption: The crowd assembled in the parking lot of Durham 's police headquarters for the Wallace-for-president rally.
Images.alt_text: A very large crowd of people stands in front of the Durham police headquarters.
Images.attribution: Durham Herald Sun.
Images.citation: Durham Civil Rights Heritage Project Collection (NCC.0040), North Carolina Collection, Durham County Library, NC

events.Text: George Wallace holds a political rally in Durham as part of his 1968 Presidential bid as a third party candidate with the American Independent Party.
events.Headline: George Wallace Presidential Campaign Rally
events.Name: 1968: George Wallace Presidential Campaign Rally

External Resource Links.Resource Title: Women-In-Action for the Prevention of Violence and Its Causes, Inc., Durham Chapter records

events.Text: Elna Spaulding forms biracial Women in Action for the Prevention of Violence.
events.Name: 1968: Elna Spaulding forms biracial Women in Action for the Prevention of Violence.

events.Text: Civil Rights Act of 1968 outlaws discrimination in the sale or rental of housing.
events.Name: 1968: Civil Rights Act of 1968 outlaws discrimination in the sale or rental of housing.

External Resource Links.Resource Title: Assassination of Martin Luther King, Jr.

events.Text: Reverend Martin Luther King, Jr. assassinated in Memphis, Tennessee.  Riots erupt in cities across the United States.
events.Headline: Reverend Martin Luther King Jr. assassinated
events.Name: 1968: Reverend Martin Luther King Jr. assassinated

events.Text: Protesters at South Carolina State University in Orangeburg, South Carolina protesting against the racial segregation of a bowling alley are shot by the South Carolina Highway Patrol.  Three African-American protesters are killed and twenty-eight are injured.
events.Name: 1968: Protesters at South Carolina State University in Orangeburg, South Carolina protesting against the racial segregation of a bowling alley are shot by the South Carolina Highway Patrol.  Three African-American protesters are killed and twenty-eight are injured.

External Resource Links.Resource Title: Student Activism at Duke University - Allen Building Takeover
Timeline of the Allen Building Takeover and its aftermath

Images.caption: Students inside Allen Building talk with students on the outside during demonstration at Duke when students took over the Allen Building on February 13, 1969.
Images.alt_text: Two African-American people inside a building peer through a window.
Images.attribution: Photographer: Harold Moore, Durham Morning Herald.
Images.citation: Durham Civil Rights Heritage Project Collection (NCC.0040), North Carolina Collection, Durham County Library, NC

Images.caption: Members of the N.C. Highway Patrol and the Durham Police with riot sticks and tear gas gun in hand, stand in front of side entrance to the Allen Building on Duke's west campus.
Images.alt_text: A group of officers wearing gas masks and carrying batons stand together.
Images.attribution: Photographer: Harold Moore, Durham Herald Sun.
Images.citation: Durham Civil Rights Heritage Project Collection (NCC.0040), North Carolina Collection, Durham County Library, NC

Images.caption: Tear gas disperses the crowd of onlookers and supporters assembled around Duke's Allen Administration Building during its takeover by Afro-American Society members and supporters.
Images.alt_text: White people running outside with tear gas all around.
Images.attribution: Photographer: Harold Moore, Durham Herald Sun.
Images.citation: Durham Civil Rights Heritage Project Collection (NCC.0040), North Carolina Collection, Durham County Library, NC

events.Text: Dozens of students, most from the Afro-American Society, barricade themselves in the Allen Building at Duke University.  Demands included an African-American studies department, a black student union, protection from police harassment, and increased enrollment and financial support for black students.  The Duke administration issued an ultimatum demanding the students leave the building or the police would be called.  People leaving the building led to clashes with police who fired tear gas into the crowd, leading to further protests.
events.Headline: Allen Building Takeover
events.Name: 1969: Allen Building Takeover

Images.caption: Black students leave the campus after vacating the Allen Administration Building in the wake of its takeover to protest the campus racial climate.
Images.alt_text: A large group of primarily African-American people with the Duke Chapel in the background. They carry a banner that reads "Malcolm X Liberation School."
Images.attribution: Photographer: Bill Boyarsky
Images.citation: Durham Civil Rights Heritage Project Collection (NCC.0040), North Carolina Collection, Durham County Library, NC

Images.caption: Founder Howard Fuller talks to a student in front of Malcolm X Liberation University, the alternative university in downtown Durham founded in protest of Duke's racial climate.
Images.alt_text: Howard Fuller and an unidentified student stand in front of a building with a sign that reads "Malcom X Liberation University."
Images.attribution: Photographer: Bill Boyarsky
Images.citation: Durham Civil Rights Heritage Project Collection (NCC.0040), North Carolina Collection, Durham County Library, NC

Images.caption: Community organizer Howard Fuller (right) and an unidentified man sit at the registration table for the Malcolm X Liberation University in Durham, spring 1969.
Images.alt_text: An unidentifed man and Howard Fuller sit behind a table covered in a banner that says "Malcolm X Liberation University."
Images.attribution: Photographer: Harold Moore, Durham Herald Sun
Images.citation: Durham Civil Rights Heritage Project Collection (NCC.0040), North Carolina Collection, Durham County Library, NC

events.Text: Activist Howard Fuller and some of the student participants in the Allen Building Takeover open Malcolm X Liberation University.  The focus of the school would be on African-American and Pan-African studies and the staff would be predominantly black.  The school operated until 1973
events.Headline: Malcolm X Liberation University
events.Name: 1969: Malcolm X Liberation University

events.Text: Federal court orders immediate racial balancing in Durham city schools.
events.Name: 1970: Federal court orders immediate racial balancing in Durham city schools.

events.Text: Voting Rights Act of 1965 renewed.
events.Name: 1970: Voting Rights Act of 1965 renewed.

External Resource Links.Resource Title: Swann v. Charlotte-Mecklenburg Board of Education

events.Text: Supreme Court upholds busing for integration in _Swann v. Charlotte-Mecklenburg Board_.
events.Name: 1971: Supreme Court upholds busing for integration in Swann v. Charlotte-Mecklenburg Board.

External Resource Links.Resource Title: Save Our Schools - 1971 Dialogue About Integration
External Resource Links.Source (Shortform): Durham Civil and Human Rights Map

events.Text: Black activist Ann Atwater and Ku Klux Klan leader C. P. Ellis chair two-week Save Our Schools charette.  The goal of the charette was to develop a peaceful way to integrate Durham public schools.
events.Headline: Ann Atwater and C. P. Ellis lead the Save Our Schools Charette
events.Name: 1971: Ann Atwater and C. P. Ellis lead the Save Our Schools Charette

External Resource Links.Resource Title: Regents of the Univ. of Cal. v. Bakke

events.Text: _Regents of the University of California v. Bakke_ bars racial quotas for college admissions but affirms the constitutionality of affirmative action programs.
events.Name: 1978: Regents of the University of California v. Bakke bars racial quotas for college admissions but affirms the constitutionality of affirmative action programs.

events.Text: Ronald Reagan established Martin Luther King Jr. Day (MLK Day) as a federal holiday to be observed on the third Monday of January.  The holiday was first observed on January 20, 1986.
events.Name: 1983: Ronald Reagan established Martin Luther King Jr. Day (MLK Day) as a federal holiday to be observed on the third Monday of January.  The holiday was first observed on January 20, 1986.

events.Text: Jack Bond becomes Durham County's first African-American county manager
events.Name: 1985: Jack Bond becomes Durham County's first African-American county manager

External Resource Links.Resource Title: Chester Jenkins, City Councilman and Mayor of Durham

events.Text: Chester Jenkins becomes first black mayor of Durham
events.Name: 1989: Chester Jenkins becomes first black mayor of Durham

events.Text: Riots break in Los Angeles after four Los Angeles Police officers were acquitted for excessive violence and beating of Rodney King during his arrest.  King's arrest had been videotaped and widely televised.  The riots last 6 days and 63 people were killed.
events.Name: 1992: Riots break in Los Angeles after four Los Angeles Police officers were acquitted for excessive violence and beating of Rodney King during his arrest.  King's arrest had been videotaped and widely televised.  The riots last 6 days and 63 people were killed.

events.Text: The Million Man March was organized by Louis Farrakhan of Nation of Islam and Dr. Benjamin Chavis of the NAACP.  With a crowd estimated between 400,000 and 1,100,000 people, it was the largest gathering of African-Americans in American history.
events.Name: 1995: The Million Man March was organized by Louis Farrakhan of Nation of Islam and Dr. Benjamin Chavis of the NAACP.  With a crowd estimated between 400,000 and 1,100,000 people, it was the largest gathering of African-Americans in American history.

events.Text: James Byrd Jr. is murdered by white supremacists in Jasper, Texas.  The murder evoked imagery of lynchings.  His killers were the first white men sentenced to death for killing a black person in the history of Texas.
events.Name: 1998: James Byrd Jr. is murdered by white supremacists in Jasper, Texas.  The murder evoked imagery of lynchings.  His killers were the first white men sentenced to death for killing a black person in the history of Texas.

events.Text: Senator Barack Obama of Illinois is elected the 44th President of the United States, the first African-American to hold the office.
events.Headline: Barack Obama becomes first African-American President of the United States
events.Name: 2008: Barack Obama becomes first African-American President of the United States

events.Text: Trayvon Martin, an unarmed 17-year-old, is killed by George Zimmerman, a neighborhood watch coordinator in Sanford, Florida.  Zimmerman claimed he shot Martin in self-defense.  Zimmerman was acquitted of second-degree murder and manslaughter under the "Stand Your Ground" law in Florida.
events.Name: 2012: Trayvon Martin, an unarmed 17-year-old, is killed by George Zimmerman, a neighborhood watch coordinator in Sanford, Florida.  Zimmerman claimed he shot Martin in self-defense.  Zimmerman was acquitted of second-degree murder and manslaughter under the "Stand Your Ground" law in Florida.

events.Text: The Black Live Matter movement is created after the acquittal of George Zimmerman.  Born out of an online hashtag (#BlackLivesMatter), the Black Lives Matter movement advocates against police violence towards black people and to eradicate white supremacy.
events.Headline: Black Lives Matter movement created
events.Name: 2013: Black Lives Matter movement created

events.Text: Michael Brown, a black unarmed 18-year-old, is fatally shot by white police officer Darren Wilson in Ferguson, Missouri.  The incident led to unrest in Ferguson and the creation of the protest slogan "Hands up, don't shoot" typically chanted at protests against police violence.  Darren Wilson was later not indicted by a Grand Jury, leading to further protests.
events.Name: 2014: Michael Brown, a black unarmed 18-year-old, is fatally shot by white police officer Darren Wilson in Ferguson, Missouri.  The incident led to unrest in Ferguson and the creation of the protest slogan "Hands up, don't shoot" typically chanted at protests against police violence.  Darren Wilson was later not indicted by a Grand Jury, leading to further protests.

events.Text: Nine churchgoers were murdered during a Bible study at Emanuel African Methodist Episcopal Church in Charleston, South Carolina, by a white supremacist.  The murderer posted photos of himself posing with white supremacist iconography including the Confederate battle flag.  The shooting led to debates about memorialization of the Confederacy and display of the flag.  In the aftermath of the shooting, the South Carolina General Assembly voted to remove the Confederate battle flag from State Capitol grounds.
events.Name: 2015: Nine churchgoers were murdered during a Bible study at Emanuel African Methodist Episcopal Church in Charleston, South Carolina, by a white supremacist.  The murderer posted photos of himself posing with white supremacist iconography including the Confederate battle flag.  The shooting led to debates about memorialization of the Confederacy and display of the flag.  In the aftermath of the shooting, the South Carolina General Assembly voted to remove the Confederate battle flag from State Capitol grounds.

events.Text: Unite the Right Rally, a meeting of white supremacist, alt-right, Klansmen, and neo-Nazis, occurs in Charlottesville, Virginia.  This racist event turned violent when alt-right protesters clashed with counter-protesters, culminating in a white supremacist deliberately driving his car into a crowd of counter-protesters, killing Heather Heyer.
events.Name: 2017: Unite the Right Rally, a meeting of white supremacist, alt-right, Klansmen, and neo-Nazis, occurs in Charlottesville, Virginia.  This racist event turned violent when alt-right protesters clashed with counter-protesters, culminating in a white supremacist deliberately driving his car into a crowd of counter-protesters, killing Heather Heyer.

External Resource Links.Resource Title: Protesters topple Confederate soldier statue in downtown Durham
“Make Racists Afraid Again”: The Scene as Demonstrators Toppled a Confederate Monument in Durham Monday

Images.caption: Law enforcement looks on after demonstrators toppled a Confederate monument in front of the old Durham County courthouse building on August 14, 2017, before marching down Main Street.
Images.alt_text: The fallen monument lays crumpled on the grass with the stone base in the background. Law enforcement officers survey the scene.
Images.attribution: Photographer: Sarah Willets
Images.citation: Durham Historic Photographic Archive (NCC.0055), North Carolina Collection, Durham County Library, NC

events.Text: Protestors topple the Confederate monument in front of the old Durham County Courthouse.  The protest began as a rally and reflection on the violence that occurred the previous weekend at the Unite the Right Rally in Charlottesville, Virginia.
events.Headline: Protestors topple the Durham County Confederate monument
events.Event Page: Toppling of the Downtown Confederate Monument, 2017
events.Name: 2017: Protestors topple the Durham County Confederate monument

events.Text: George Floyd is killed while being arrested when a white Minneapolis police officer knelt on his neck for over eight minutes while three other officers looked on.  Floyd's death sparked thousands of protests against police violence across the United States and around the world, despite the COVID-19 pandemic.  Many protests were met with excessive force from the police.  The protests have led to the removal of Confederate monuments and calls for police reform.
events.Headline: George Floyd's murder sparks massive protests against police violence
events.Name: 2020: George Floyd's murder sparks massive protests against police violence

events.Text: Ahmaud Arbery is killed by three white men while jogging through a neighborhood in Brunswick, Georgia.  None of the suspects were arrested or charged until a video was released of the incident. The inaction by the police and the district attorney's office sparked debates about racial inequality in the United States.
events.Name: 2020: Ahmaud Arbery is killed by three white men while jogging through a neighborhood in Brunswick, Georgia.  None of the suspects were arrested or charged until a video was released of the incident. The inaction by the police and the district attorney's office sparked debates about racial inequality in the United States.

Images.caption: "A Bull's City" by Mack Wilson-Leigh, Eric Cabbell, Jr. and other members of the Raleigh Art Night group.  The artwork was located at The Oak House at 126 West Main Street.
Images.alt_text: A mural with a blue background displaying buildings, raised "power" fists as flowers, a bull, and the words "Black Lives Matter," "A change will come," and "No justice no peace."
Images.attribution: Photographer: Elizabeth Shulman
Images.citation: Downtown Durham Protest Murals (NCC.0238), North Carolina Collection, Durham County Library, NC

Images.caption: James Baldwin Mural by Anthony Patterson, located at MDC Inc. at 307 West Main Street.
Images.alt_text: A red mural depicting James Baldwin and the words "the power of the white world is threatened whenever a black person refuses to accept the white world's definition. - James Baldwin, The Fire Next Time."
Images.attribution: Photographer: Elizabeth Shulman
Images.citation: Downtown Durham Protest Murals (NCC.0238), North Carolina Collection, Durham County Library, NC

Images.caption: "Royalty," by LA Jarome Chesson.  The mural was originally located at Area Modern Home at 101 West Chapel Hill Street. Photograph was taken after the mural was relocated to Main Street near 9th Street Bakery.
Images.alt_text: The faces of a black man and woman made to appear as though light is shining from their eyes. The words "royalty," "we don't die we multiply," and "we need you to feel us, not just hear us!" appear.
Images.attribution: Photographer: Elizabeth Shulman
Images.citation: Downtown Durham Protest Murals (NCC.0238), North Carolina Collection, Durham County Library, NC

events.Text: Protestors peacefully protest in downtown Durham against police violence after the murder of George Floyd in Minneapolis, Minnesota.  After violence in other cities, businesses boarded up their windows to deter against rioting and looting.  Instead of violence, artists painted protest murals on the boards.  Many businesses kept the boards on their windows as a way of displaying the art, even after the physical protests ended.
events.Headline: Durham Protest Murals
events.Name: 2020: Durham Protest Murals
